Attached is Firebird-v3.0.  
  
In an attempt to minimize bad effect of strong up or down market movements, I have coded a new Firebird to use iFXAnalyzer as an up and down strong trend indicator. The EA will not place trades during strong up or down trends indicated by chart message "Market Trending up" or "Market Trending Down". I added a Hedge function option to place reverse trade when PipStep trade is triggered. Hedge orders have ability to increase lot size. I cleaned up the EA and now there are no warnings when compiled in MetaEditor. Other added functions are described below. 

  1. UseEquityProtection -if true, close all orders when negative Float is excessvie.
  2. FloatPercent –percent of balance for equity protection.
  3. UseMM-money management.
  4. Risk-pecent of account equity to risk per trade.
  5. MaxOpenOrders-sets maximum number of open trades at same time.
  6. MinMarginLevel-below minimum Margin Level percent % trading stops.
  7. CloseDays-number of days trade is open before auto closing.
  8. LossLevel-loss amount before auto closing after Closedays.
  9. UseHedge-if true, places reverse order with PipStep order.
  10. HedgeLotFactor-hedge order Lots will be increased by this factor.
  11. HedgeTakeProfit-
  12. HedgeStopLoss-
  13. AutoCal-if true, iRSI() calculation of TakeProfit, StopLoss and PipStep. (not hedge orders)

This Firebird, as well as most other versions, is very slow in backtest. I can assure the added EA functions work. In backtest with default settings, it performed well on eurusd. gbpusd backtest was a bit shakey, but still in profit. I have not tested other pairs. I hope it performs well in Demo and Live accounts. I found better profits when HedgeLotFactor is set between 2-4.   
  
Warning: The success or failure of this Expert Advisor is the exclusive responsibility of the Enduser.  
  
Wackena

I 've been following goblin closely for quite a few days, and the discussion there really made me think a lot.  
  
Personally, I think goblin is still not a real trend following system, but very much an EA with martingale method playing the main role, and I made a suggestion to transform it into a true trend following system with martingale method playing a supporting role.  
  
I think for firebird, it would also be good to transform it into a daily trend following system. We could let it follow the daily trend by using whatever indicator we feel comfortable with. We only buy in an uptrend and sell in a downtrend. And in the daily trend, there must be minor trends against it, which firebird can take advantage of them by using its strength of 'buy on dip and sell on rally'.  
  
A daily uptrend and downtrend usually lasts a few days, firebird should be good in this period. The drawdown would be the potential loss incurred at the transional period, the period market changes from bull to bear, or from bear to bull, or in the daily sideway market. Shall we cut our existing positions when there is a signal of direction change of daily trend? I think only when the averaging loss reached certain level. If we cut them too early, we might suffer in a typical sideway market. If we cut too late, we will be against a big move.  
  
For this idea, I am really not sure about its possibility of success. Just for you guys to see if it is worth trying.

Glenn,  
  
How many orders were opened?  
  
If UseMM=true, the lot size is a calculation based on Risk% of AccountEquity. If lot size is larger than you want, reduce Risk %.   
Example:  
AccountEquity = $10,000  
Risk=10;  
Then Lots will be 1.0 for 1st trade. 1st Hedge trade Lot size is Lots * HedgeLotFactor. In same example, if HedgeLotFactor=3, then 1st Hedge trade will have Lots = 3.0. For same lot size on both normal and Hedge, set HedgeLotFactor=1.  
  
If UseMM=false, then you manually set the Lots variable to whatever lot size you want. Hedge lot calculation is same as above.  
  
Wackena

As requested by Michaelw, I have coded a Trade Time scheduler into latest Firebird v3.0. It is a little bit of overkill. But, it will allow to schedule up to 4 "Trading Time" zones per day and a full week's schedule to be set at one time.  
  
If UseTradeScheduler=true, then the following applies.  
  
Each "Trading Time" zone 1 through 4 has a Start and an End for each day.   
To trade all day , set "day"...Start1=0 and "day"...End4=24. This is needed for each trading day.  
To skip a full day, set "day"...Start1=0 and "day"...End4=0.  
  
**Note: EA is coded to use your Local PC Time.**  
  
Here is a Monday example.   
  
MonTradeHourStart1 = 0; - _(Trading Time zone 1 start)_  
MonTradeHourEnd1 = 8; - _(Trading Time zone 1 end)_   
MonTradeHourStart2 = 10;   
MonTradeHourEnd2 = 16;

nvwine,  
I see similar hedge order openings as you report. This is the way I hoped this EA would work. The Hedge Order call is controlled by PipStep call and MaxOpenOrders setting. On call for PipStep order, a Hedge Order is also called. The number of Hedge orders is controlled by MaxOpenOrders setting. Example: if MaxOpenOrders=5:   
  
1st order is normal EA call.  
2nd normal order and 1st Hedge Order are on 1st PipStep call.  
3rd normal order and 2nd Hedge Order are on 2nd PipStep call.  
  
I think what is happening is if 1st Hedge order closes before 3rd normal order is open, it throws the complete sequence off. I will investigate the sequence this weekend.   
  
Wackena

Firebird 3.2  
  
[Broker](http://www.forexfactory.com/index.php?page=forex_brokers) FXDD - eurusd, gbpusd, usdjpy, usdchf  
Deposit $3,000  
Timeframe M5  
Balance $5,120  
Equity $4,779  
Wins 72 - Loses 7  
Open Orders 4 (Float p/l $-340)  
ROI 25.9 %  
  
Started test on 2006.12.03.  
  
I had 7 loses, that were my fault. They comprised of 2 groups, 1st for 2 loses and 2nd for 5 loses. 1st group was when I started the test and had PercentFloatLevel=10. This only allows negative Float to be 10% of Balance before it closes all orders. 2nd group of loses was when I broke a basic rule of never working on a code if EA is running. I set the equity proctection level again too low and it closed all open orders again. you can see none of the loses were sl loses. If I hadn't made these 2 miistakes, I should be up even more by a few hundred dollars with no loses.  
  
This doesn't it mean that Firebird 3.2 won't blowup sometime in the future, but it survived the NFP news on Friday. The Hedge orders seem to be very useful in making profits during both trend directions. We will need to wait and see a few major trend spikes before we know if this EA can play and not get hurt too bad in the real world.  
  
Firebird is a counter trend EA and needs a range of negative float to perform as designed. I suggest that PercentFloatLevel setting be set to allow ~$1,000 per each lot for negative float. Example: 1 lot = ten orders of 0.1 lot. To protect equity, PercentFloatLevel needs to be adjusted as equity increases. On equity increases, PercentFloatLevel can be set lower to maintain necessary amount for negative float.  
  
I can not over state the importance of protecting your equity when running Firebird EAs. It's history has been to make real impressive profits over time, just to see it quickly get wipe out in only a few days. Use the equity protection, trading time filter, manual observations or whatever it takes.  
  
Wackena

The hedge orders should be triggered along with PipStep orders. For some reason, part of the original Firebird code that tracks open orders gets confused and loses track sometimes of 1 to 2 orders. As stated this part of the original code and I will investigate possible fix.  
  
The concern I have had with all Firebird versions is its inability to handle long sustained trends. It likes long ranging markets that moves within a 300 to 500 pips range, It's true that FB3.2 with the hedge feature does better, but it also has this same problem. When we have long sustained trends like we are having now on the 4 major pairs, FB is going to get caught with open orders that keep drifting toward the StopLoss. This is usually seen after a few days and you see 1 or 2 orders on a chart that has been open for a few days. The Stoploss could be set at 500 and this would only delay the inevitable loss.  
  
Well with that being said, I think FB needs a routine to close all orders, on a pair, when the sum of all orders are in profit. With FB3.2 present default settings, Hedge orders lots are 3 times higher than standard order lot size. This should allow a point in time where the Hedge profit minus all open orders is still a profit. I think this should be a turn on - turn off function and it will be up to the user to determine if in long trending or long ranging market.  
  
Wackena

enable the Allow Live trade ( and if you like to allow the manula confirmation )  
  
if you did all that you shoud see a smily face at the right top corner of the chart..

if it is happy ( smile one ) then it is working ,

I agree with you that risk can't be totally avoided and is part of the game.  
But my personal opinion is that float should always be kept at a minimum.  
1] Because it gives a better starting point for conditions when trends really get out of hand.  
2] Even when the huge float turns into winners it doesn't mean it's very profiteble. If the money wasn't tied up you could possibly have made several winning smaller trades.  
3] Huge float earns less when you follow RM/MM rules.  
4] The money you set aside to buffer the huge DD that occure once every 100 trades means that that money isn't earning in 99 trades. But smart MM/RM can improve that situation to some extend.  
  
More on Risk Management and Money Management.  
MM/RM is no fix. It's a magnifying glass.  
It fools you when testing. It hides the real system performance.  
A system should be profiteble without MM/RM. Only then start using RM/MM  
  
MM/RM is not just scaling a few lots as seen in most EAs (but soem MM is a very good start). It's a real art that can get very complex. But it has great advantage. Not only safty wise but also speeding up portfolio growth. There is a lot of info to be found on MM/RM. If you can't find any you can start looking here <http://www.adaptrade.com/Articles/article-op.htm> Also play with their program. It's awsome.  
Also read a bit about Sharpe and/or Sortino Ratio.  
It will learn you that decent MM/RM punishes you for having a system with a huge DD. It cuts down the max. allowed lots because it keeps being paranoid about the possibility of the DD.  
As an example a huge DD system (with massive gains if it reverses) is allowed to trade 5 lots and and a system that just keeps collecting a few pips in many short lasting trades may be allowed to trade 15 lots just because it feels/is so safe.  
So the 'smooth system' collects 3x more $ per pip earned. 

May the pips be with you.

> Quoting TraderSeven

> I agree with you that risk can't be totally avoided and is part of the game.  
>  But my personal opinion is that float should always be kept at a minimum.  
>  1] Because it gives a better starting point for conditions when trends really get out of hand.  
>  2] Even when the huge float turns into winners it doesn't mean it's very profiteble. If the money wasn't tied up you could possibly have made several winning smaller trades.  
>  3] Huge float earns less when you follow RM/MM rules.  
>  4] The money you set aside to buffer the huge DD that occure once every 100 trades means that that money isn't earning in 99 trades. But smart MM/RM can improve that situation to some extend.  
>    
>  More on Risk Management and Money Management.  
>  MM/RM is no fix. It's a magnifying glass.  
>  It fools you when testing. It hides the real system performance.  
>  A system should be profiteble without MM/RM. Only then start using RM/MM  
>    
>  MM/RM is not just scaling a few lots as seen in most EAs (but soem MM is a very good start). It's a real art that can get very complex. But it has great advantage. Not only safty wise but also speeding up portfolio growth. There is a lot of info to be found on MM/RM. If you can't find any you can start looking here <http://www.adaptrade.com/Articles/article-op.htm> Also play with their program. It's awsome.  
>  Also read a bit about Sharpe and/or Sortino Ratio.  
>  It will learn you that decent MM/RM punishes you for having a system with a huge DD. It cuts down the max. allowed lots because it keeps being paranoid about the possibility of the DD.  
>  As an example a huge DD system (with massive gains if it reverses) is allowed to trade 5 lots and and a system that just keeps collecting a few pips in many short lasting trades may be allowed to trade 15 lots just because it feels/is so safe.  
>  So the 'smooth system' collects 3x more $ per pip earned.

I've only applied this theory to Eur/Aud but it should work for the majors also because if cable ranges, the majors should follow.

In my opinion:  
  
EA's are trading tools. Firebird is a great tool for a specific set of market conditions. I wouldn't use a wrench to hammer a nail... I increased my live account 50% with this tool, and I held on to my gains. Not bragging... I'm sure many traders did better with it than I did, but they're probably tired of hearing the same old complaints after repeated warnings. Anyone who studies this thread will see that it is rife with cautionary posts about the fact that this EA is not for inexperienced traders. Does that make it a "bad" program? No.   
  
In fact, I don't believe new traders should waste their time with EA's at all for at least the first year or two. All the same rules apply to profitable manual trading. Learn to trade manually (and profitably) before working on anything like this. Retail Forex vendors don't provide Metatrader with it's automated trading capabilities because they think it will make traders more money. Going back to the tool analogy... if someone hasn't learned to effectively use a hand saw yet, then they'll make a bloody mess with a power saw.

The last version that I coded is Firebird 3.2 and is attached. Other versions are located here.  
<http://www.accrete.com/fx-mirror/mt4-firebird/>  
  
I've found out the hard way that Firebird (any version) will lose money if not manually controlled when needed. FB is a reverse trend EA in that it waits till price reaches either upper band and enters sell order or lower band to enter buy order. The concept is that the price will eventually reverse to take profit. Before it reverses, PipStep orders will be placed while price continues to move up (Sell PipStep orders) or down (Buy PipStep orders). If the trend continues, the 300 pips Stoploss gives possibility of many PipStep orders. This can lead to high DrawDowns. You much decide if trend is worth staying in or manually close order/s for small lost. Also, in most instances, the price never reverses enough to close all orders in profit. So you much also decide when to close a long term open order.   
  
This is experience only, no set rules. If you can learn when to stay in and when to get out, this EA can make profits as I have run 3.2 in profit for several months.  
  
The hedge function places both Buy and Sell orders when PipStep order is called. I've found this improves profits, but will also have more occurrences where manually intervention is needed.  
  
The MA_timeframe=15 and I have not changed this. On M5 chart selection, you will have more orders and higher DrawDowns. Lately I use M30 chart selection and it seems to slow down number of trades and reduced high DrawDowns. I think M30 predicts trends better.  
  
The EquityProtection feature in 3.2 is not the best code. Setting the Float Percent correctly needs to be constantly changed in relation to Account Balance, and so, I don't use it.  
  
Wackena

>  I've found out the hard way that Firebird (any version) will lose money if not manually controlled when needed. FB is a reverse trend EA in that it waits till price reaches either upper band and enters sell order or lower band to enter buy order. The concept is that the price will eventually reverse to take profit. Before it reverses, PipStep orders will be placed while price continues to move up (Sell PipStep orders) or down (Buy PipStep orders). If the trend continues, the 300 pips Stoploss gives possibility of many PipStep orders. This can lead to high DrawDowns. You much decide if trend is worth staying in or manually close order/s for small lost. Also, in most instances, the price never reverses enough to close all orders in profit. So you much also decide when to close a long term open order.   
>    
>  This is experience only, no set rules. If you can learn when to stay in and when to get out, this EA can make profits as I have run 3.2 in profit for several months.  
>    
>  The hedge function places both Buy and Sell orders when PipStep order is called. I've found this improves profits, but will also have more occurrences where manually intervention is needed.  
>    
>  The MA_timeframe=15 and I have not changed this. On M5 chart selection, you will have more orders and higher DrawDowns. Lately I use M30 chart selection and it seems to slow down number of trades and reduced high DrawDowns. I think M30 predicts trends better.  
>    
>  The EquityProtection feature in 3.2 is not the best code. Setting the Float Percent correctly needs to be constantly changed in relation to Account Balance, and so, I don't use it.  
>    
>  Wackena

  * | Joined Nov 2005  | Status: EA trader | [146 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=4635)

Thanks skyline for the useful information.  
I think the most important thing for those newbies who wants to try firebird is to know that "THERE IS NO MONEY MANAGEMENT BUILD INTO FIREBIRD" and I think that's the killer. People play big with firebird in the hope to make massive money (but they most likely lost the account).  
Take example that you only want to try one pair USD/CHF and get those 40000+PIPs over last 1 and half year, what's the money management you should use?  
The drawdown is 4000PIPs, so to be safe, we double it to 8000PIPs that the pips you need to survive the drawdown. Then say your maximum tolerance risk for your account is 20% drawdown. If you have US$10000 on "mini" account, then you can only risk $2000 total for that 8000PIPS - that translate to 0.25 lot per trade. Then those 40000 PIPs profit would translate $10000 profit over last 1 1/2 years which is pretty good. It is just not matching the "NEWBIE'S EXPECTATION"~~  
Then it is the question of "diversification" - people expected that diversification is good and think it can "minimise" the drawdown. However it is not true for firebird~~ The drawdown are more severe with diversification and believe me it eats all your profit before you ever noticed it. Therefore if you really want to diversify, you need to reduce the trade size further.  
  
By the way, the backtesting using firebird gives totally different result to the live trade so don't backtest it and think you got the holy grail.  
  
Hope it helps everyone.

I totally agree with Skyline.  
  
I also traded this EA live . You can see my results earlier in this thread. My risk per trade was 3% and the EA gave great results for several months. Then I lost most of my account in a few weeks during a strong trend. I nearly lost the lot but manually bailed out with 50% or my starting balance. before this period i was up 70%. So starting with a $1,000 account I ran it up to $1,700, then lost $1,200 in a few weeks. Not good.  
  
Do not be decieved by good results for a period of time. 30 pips profits with 300 pip losses will nuke your account sooner or later.   
  
I actually tested this EA with great results for a few months then went live thinking I was now on "easy street". trading this EA went against all that i had come to believe about a good system - but the results were great so it must be good. Certainly this EA give periods with great results but the inevitable losses will wipe you out.  
  
I have attatched my statement as proof. Please refer to the first half of the atatched graph. This is not my only trading account. I mostly use this one for testing, but it's clear that this EA has some serious problems.   
  
Learn to trade properly. Do not waste your time and money with this EA. If you want to trade EAs find one with better stats. personally i would rather learn to trade the "hard" way.  
  
I gave up on EAs after this one, and am slowly rebuilding my account.  
  
There is no easy way. I have certainly learnt that lesson after 4 years of trading. The lessons I have learnt in that time cannot be taught in any other way.  
  
Please do not be deceived by EAs like this. I don;t know what else to say but I feel for people who get caught by in the trap of what at first appears to be "easy riches" only to lose everything in a matter of time.

Having tested v1.0a, I would have to say it was luck based on the market conditions. Be very careful. In a ranging market you will take profit on a few trades every day with almost no loses. The float will get large but will not be a problem because the larger the float the more you gain on a retracement. Then if the market starts trending a bunch of open trades will hit the SL. Look carefully at your float and count the possible loss if the market trends strongly. I would not recommend trading with real money. As far as trade size goes it would depend somewhat on how many pairs you trade and what you have the EA's parameters set to. I would test at .1 lots if you are trading a number of pairs.

I work with all the firebirds versions for almost a year. Firebird 63g original version is the best. I open a live account with $500 and in 5 days i have $932, no losses. The key with firebird is not be "greedy". I work with GBP/USD and USD/CAD in a 5 minutes chart. tp=26, sl=300, pipstep=30. Never work with USD/JPY. EUR/USD have big downdraws. Just open a maximun of two pairs and you will be alright. If you open four, five or six pairs at the same time your account will be destroy. Remember this is a reverse EA you will begin the trade losing points. Don"t be greed. Look at me. $432 in 5 days. Not bad.

Hi,  
  
I have used the Firebird EA v1.0c with great results. I used the original settings in the first post, with TF 1M on E/U.   
  
I gone through several posts in this thread and it seems that many traders prefer the original 63g version better than other versions. Didn't this version have problems such as multiple orders?  
  
Traders also seem to prefer G/U and USD/CAD with other timeframes than 1M. Some mention that U/J is good as well, but others say that the JPY-pairs doesn't work well.  
  
It would be interesting to know what versions of the EA that people prefer, on which pairs and timeframes? It would also be nice to know how profitable this EA has been for traders in this thread?  
  
This can be a very profitable EA, but it is aggressive, so it would be nice to hear different opinions of how to tweak the settings. Hopefully we can all learn from each other and earn some extra pips!  
  
Happy trading!

Fire Bird V1.0a   
  
It is now in my Demo chart for a about a week . The following  
are my observaton about the EA  
  
Did Back tested on all pairs from jan 08 till Aug 08 and the performance  
is 95 % ok On JPY/us$  
  
Other pairs are not performing to my expectation  
  
I did the following change in the Settings   
  
Fast EMA original 18 changed to 5  
  
Slow EMA original 24 Changed to 10  
DivergenceLimit .0002 changed to .0005  
  
The above changes are made duing my back testing process and I have found the number of loss has reduced after the change in the settings  
  
My other observations are  
  
Avoid EA during news time  
Avoid EA during market change over like Japan to UK& Europe ad the last part  
of US market

Hi guys,  
  
This is my first post on FF, although I’ve been lurking on FF forum for about a year, I see that this thread is freezing, so I just wanted to share my thought hoping for good feedbacks from all you guys. So here’s my thought,   
  
I’m busy doing my job since I’m an employee, so I wanted to have a minimum control of my chart, I just want a daily control, secondly there is no EA that works forever since the market is changing overtime so I have to “drive” the EA manually ( set the EA “Long only” or “Short only”), I’ll show you how.  
  
  
  
1. Put the EA on **5 Min chart**   
2. Put the template and indicator on your **daily chart**  
  
  
**How to start and “drive” the EA**  
1. See the trend on daily chart just like the pic below,  
2. When you see the trend down on daily chart, “Drive” the EA “Short only” on your 5 min chart, and vice versa  
3. When you see the trend is changing on daily chart then you have to “drive” your EA on 5 min chart accordingly  
  
  
Maybe theres a question, if you see the trend is clear so why you have to use this EA? My experience is that this EA can catch pips more than the market pip range , for example from January 1st Jan to January 7th the price move down for 500 pips, then this EA can catch more than 500 pips from the price retracement, just try this EA on back test for 1 month on Aug 2008 you will see that.  
  
  
Less stress because you don’t trade news and not sit in front of your computer for a long time, just check it once a day.  
  
  
I used GBPUSD and EURUSD or you can try another pair, just look for the pair that shows a clear trend in mid or long term  
  
Default setting for the EA is set to 5 digit broker platform, you can change it, and also the TP and pipstep as you feel comfort.  
  
  
I know there’s gotta be a negative side from this “EA drive” thing, I know some but I prefer to hear the feedback from you guys.  
  
  
English is not my default language, so…sory for my bad English.  
  
  
Samurai Power

"EA IS TO MAKE YOUR TRADE EASIER, NOT TO MAKE YOUR LIFE EASIER",   
so dont put all of your life on it.  
  
  
Here is my illustration,  
  
let say you set your EA to open position when the market form this condition  
  
(I ilustrate the market condition = sequence of numbers, just like below)  
  
5-4-6-8-9....   
  
when this sequence of numbers forms, the EA will open position and expected to be profit next, let say at this present this market condition generate 80% profit and 20% loss, and you happy  
  
but the market is changing soon or later, and this sequence of numbers no longer profitting, and you pee in your pants.  
  
I think the goal is how to make profit with minimum control and less stress,  
even the best strategy like 4H MACD from Phillip Nell is not 100% win, still need brain to manage money management, but with 70% probability of winning the trade.  
  
the basic of my firebird setting (see post 2090) is no different with 4H MACD P. Nell, you still need to:  
  
manage money management,  
look for a good entry setup condition,  
stay away from the unpredictable, market,   
and bla...bla...  
  
the only different is that there is one hard part from the trade that automated (so I use this EA), I say hard becouse I still pee on my pants when I open position and the market against me (can't control my emotion he...).  
  
so "DRIVE" the EA and enter the trade when the market shows a good entry setup, that's how to avoid a huge drawdown.

Without reading the whole thread (I know I should), it seems this EA is a lot like it, except you are using it only for either a long or short position based on your reading of what the daily trend is. But, isn't the issue the RETRACE and not the trend? Let's say you buy or sell the EURO, because your chart says it's trending long and it steadily climbs up 300 points, and the biggest retrace was 25 pips in that whole move. You already have several positions at increasing lot sizes, so you really can't buy anymore. Because the pair is now 125 PIPS above your last trade, you need a retrace of 80 PIPS to close all trades either even or in profit. What if it never does? What if it just keeps trending up another 400 points? That's my main concern.

I just came across this thread the other day, and see this EA has been around for awhile, and a lot of people were gung ho about it, and apparently got killed in a heavily trending market when the pair(s) just kept going up or down. There hasn't been much posting sine about September of last year.  
I've put it on 4 pairs just to see how it works. Samur, I admire your statements and that you've been able to get 100 pips consistently.  
  
On IBFX, the standard setting of.10 is ten cents. On a $3,000 account, that's good to start with. I like your idea of going with the current trend only. I suppose if you're in a trade such as the GBP, and the trend changes overnight, you can always just close that trade and go the other way. When I look back at the first post here, I see very low take profits and pipsteps. I gather someone decided those should be changed, because the v63 EA has default settings of MUCH higher pips.  
  
Does anyone know these were changed? Was it to eliminate too many trades?   
  
In future posts, I'll talk about an EA created by a guy named nanningbob that is very similar, and a new concept of opening trades at extremes when the pair exceeds it's 40 Moving Average by 80, 90, 100, 120 pips (whatever you want to set it at). This goes against the trend, and opens additional trades at whatever distance you want. It's the opposite of this EA. It's a counter trend EA.  
  
I don't see how people got busted using this EA. If you use a stop of 300 pips, you can simply calculate how much % of your account that is, and set the EA to trade only the amount of lots that would equal 2-3% of your account if you were stopped out.  
  
One of the threads nanningbob has posts on is "100X80 EA oh boy" for anyone that is interested.

I've been trying this EA also, and had it set for LONG on the EUR/USD and had trades opened. Then, the trend changed. The question is at what point do you close out these losing trades? Do you hold them & hope the trend will change back the next day? At what point do you look at the trend? New York session? Tokoyo? London? If you don't close out trades, and the trend reverses, you can have quite a few trades open that would each lose 300 PIPS. Haven't given up on this EA yet, though.  
Why is it used like it is where it opens additional trades, each subject to a 300 PIP loss? Has anyone ever tried it with 50 TP and a 150 Stop Loss? I think this is probably why people lost interest in this EA. The possibility and even PROBABILITY of huge losses when th etrend changes and you don't know whether the trend may come back to you, or not. In the meantime, you're stuck with trades that each hit a 300 PIP stop loss.

I have been Strategy Testing a program unrelated to Firebird that increases/decreases lot size based on % of changing account balances. Good idea but hard to administer. Get the lot size a little too large and margin out. Take a loss when the account balance/lot size is large and loose nine months of gain. Double ouch.  
  
The solution? Not sure. Be very conservative with the percent of lot size changes? Drain off profits all along the way, (best choice of the two) in which case the account balance does not get dangeriously high?
